description: On the 6th of July 2020, the Namibian President announced that the exponential increase of cases at Walvis Bay, the three local authority areas, namely Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis will remain under STAGE 3 for a period of 28 days from the 7th July 2020 until midnight on the 3rd August 2020. Schools in the restricted areas may not resume face-to-face instruction. Learners who find themselves in the restricted areas will not be permitted to travel out of that restricted area to other parts of the country, owing to the inherent risks.

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that comprehensive restrictions on cross border movement of persons remain in force, with exception of the transportation of essential goods. Returning citizens and permanent residents will be subjected to mandatory, supervised quarantine for a period of 14 days. Persons placed under supervised quarantine will be monitored. All Non-Namibians will not be allowed to enter the country and will be turned back, with exception of humanitarian aid workers and essential services as defined. All Namibians abroad who wish to return home must inform their Embassy or High Commission of their intent to travel, a week before departure. The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Namibia March 17th 2020

arrangements for travelers arriving in Namibia:
-Entry controls and health checks with temperature measurements / thermo scan at the border inspection posts.
-Travelers recording high temperature readings may be required to undergo compulsory
quarantine measures of the Namibian health authorities.
-All returning Namibians and permanent residents arriving from countries of high risk or from affected other countries will be subject to supervised self-quarantine from 14 days.

description:
Namibia 03-11-2020

-is putting in place capacities for screening and laboratory testing for suspected cases. Namibia Institute of Pathology (NIP) is now capacitated to conduct the COVID-19 confirmatory test locally. The Laboratory has in fact already carried out a total of four (4) tests on suspected cases to date.

-The Government procured and dispatched Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) to all 14 regions

-The Government, in collaboration with key stakeholders conducted a national training of trainers (ToT) on COVD-19. These trainers have been deployed to the regions in order to train health workers and stakeholders for COVID-19 preparedness and response

People with travel histories to and from infected countries should be screened.

description: On the 1st of April 2020, the minister of health announced the enhancing of testing facilities in Namibia. He stated that people with respiratory ailments should be given priority when testing. These tests will focus on 3 main regions namely; Koras, Khomas and Erongo.
type_sub_cat: Fixed Health Testing stations (excluding drive-ins)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that anyone with symptoms of a dry cough, high fever and shortness of breath should call the Toll-Free Number 0800-100-100 or 911 or consult a health facility or community health worker to be advised on what to do. The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.
type_sub_cat: Fixed Health Testing stations (excluding drive-ins)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that the public should wear facemasks  when using both private and public transport, shopping, outdoor group exercise and at the workplace. They should increase hygiene interventions (e.g. public hand washing utilities and consumables) including installation of sanitizer equipment within public and work places and increase cleaning and disinfecting of surfaces including public transport and all public assets, twice a week (municipal buses, play park equipment, shared water access points, public restrooms etc). The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On the 6th of July 2020, the Namibian President announced that the exponential increase of cases at Walvis Bay, the three local authority areas, namely Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis will remain under STAGE 3 for a period of 28 days from the 7th July 2020 until midnight on the 3rd August 2020. Inhabitants of the three local authority areas are urged to wear masks correctly when in public places, keep a distance of not less than 1.5 meters from one another, wash hands as frequently as possible, keep on sanitizing and refrain from touching the mouth, nose, eyes and face.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that people will be permitted to travel domestically between regions and within towns and cities, without restriction. No authorization will be required to travel. Screening will be maintained at existing checkpoints (regionally and at points of entry).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 3rd of May 2020, Air Namibia conducted a media release stating that they will start flying again locally effective 6 May 2020, following the announcement of Stage 2 under the State of Emergency. Regional and international flights remain suspended until further notice. Passengers can now fly between Eros and Ondangwa, Rundu, Katima Mulilo, Luderitz, Oranjemund and Walvis Bay. Air Namibia will conduct mandatory temperature testing on all passengers before boarding. Furthermore, all passengers are expected to wear their masks in public spaces and throughout the flight.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 6th of July 2020, the Namibian President announced that the exponential increase of cases at Walvis Bay, the three local authority areas, namely Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis will remain under STAGE 3 for a period of 28 days from the 7th July 2020 until midnight on the 3rd August 2020. The cordon to restrict the movement of people into and out of the three Local Authority Areas will be reinforced as a travel ban, with exception of the movement of essential and critical goods and services, and medical emergencies. This means that the only permits to be issued and authorized to travel into and out of the three Local Authority Areas, will be for these categories provided. Travel between other towns in the Erongo region and to the rest of the country, will be permitted, with exception of the restricted Local Authority Areas
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Namibia, March 17th: For the time being up to and including May 4, 2020, the public is encouraged to stay at home and avoid gathering people.
Purchases of food and medicines, visits to the doctor, etc. or exercise in groups of max. three people are allowed. Only one person can make purchases per household.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 14th, 2020. The Namibian Government extended the national lockdown from midnight on Friday 17th April 2020 to midnight on 4th May 2020. The country will reopen on 5th May 2020. During this period, movements within the whole country will be restricted.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 31st of July 2020, Namibian president delivered a presidential address stating that Erongo Region is currently the epicenter in our fight against this invisible enemy. The current STAGE 3 level of restriction is due to lapse at midnight on Monday 3 August 2020. I hereby inform the nation that the Erongo Region and the special dispensation for the Local Authority Areas of Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis will remain unchanged and is hereby extended from Tuesday 4 August until midnight on Monday 31 August 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 6, 2020, additional measures have been implemented in the Local Authority Areas of Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis in Namibia. The introduction of these measures is done with the sole objective of containing the spread of disease within and beyond these three towns. Townships which are crowded have been identified, and alternative housing arrangements have been provided. 60 mass houses in Walvis Bay and 100 mass houses in Swakopmund have been identified for this population.
type_text: Government identified townships in infected areas to be over crowded, and provided other areas or houses for them to live during this pandemic to help stop the spread of the virus.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 31st of July 2020, Namibian president delivered a presidential address stating that the other 13 regions of the country will remain under STAGE 4 level of restrictions, with the following revised measures to curb the spread of the virus. Contact sports will be permitted, but no spectators allowed. Unregistered sports activities that draw crowds must be discouraged in the communities.
type_text: Restriction on sporting matches, to curb the gathering of spectators
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Namibian government announced on 17 September 2020 that effective from the 18th of September 2020 the State of Emergency will come to an end. That means that international travel resumes for both national and foreign travellers . Travelers are required to present a negative COVID-19 test obtained within the previous 72 hours prior to boarding a flight and no compulsory quarantine is required.  curfew is also lifted as well as movement restrictions between regions (provinces).
type_text: The nationwide state of emergency has been lifted and come to an end on 18 September 2020. International commercial passenger travel would resume, as of 18 September 2020. Authorities also announced that restrictions in place including restrictions on non-essential movement and the curfew, have been lifted. Entry and exit restrictions have also been removed from the capital, Windhoek, the Khomas Region, and the cities of Rehoboth and Okahandja. Public gatherings are still limited to 50 people; however, nightclubs and casinos may now operate.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that most businesses where social distancing is possible will be permitted to reopen, subject to responsible personal and organizational conduct and in compliance with the Health & Hygiene Guidelines. Business that are not open for business are; Theatres; cinemas; Gyms and exercise centers; Contact sports and sporting events; Gambling houses; nightclubs; Entertainment events and concerts; Liquor outlets, bars and shebeens; Seminars, Conferences, Workshops and Summits. The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.

description:
Namibia suspended on 03-14-2020 all big gatherings for a period of 30 days.
The Independence Celebrations that were scheduled for Independence Stadium are called off. However, the swearing-in-ceremony will take place at State House. The financial outlay for Independence Celebrations will be diverted to the fight against the Coronavirus.
Namibia 03-24-2020, The Public is urged to remain at home and avoid public gatherings at places such as bars, Shebeens, nightclubs and markets. The law enforcement organs to enforce these measures.

The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that restrictions on public gatherings should be observed across the country. Any gathering during this period may not exceed more than 10 persons. This includes weddings and funerals. Conveners of gatherings are required to keep attendance register, in any eventuality.  The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 6th of July 2020, the Namibian President announced that the exponential increase of cases at Walvis Bay, the three local authority areas, namely Walvis Bay, Swakopmund and Arandis will remain under STAGE 3 for a period of 28 days from the 7th July 2020 until midnight on the 3rd August 2020. Public gatherings shall remain restricted to a maximum of 10 people for the whole of Erongo Region
type_sub_cat: All/Unspecified mass gatherings
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 31st of July 2020, Namibian president delivered a presidential address stating that the other 13 regions of the country will remain under STAGE 4 level of restrictions, with the following revised measures to curb the spread of the virus. Public gatherings are reduced from 250 to 100 persons.
type_sub_cat: All/Unspecified mass gatherings
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Namibia is enforcing a restriction on public gatherings which would take effect on 13 January 2021 and will continue for 21 days till 3 March 2021. Public gatherings are to be maintained at a maximum capacity of 50 persons, social distancing of 2 meters are to be implemented to the attending persons and should not exceed 8 pm.
type_sub_cat: All/Unspecified mass gatherings
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Namibia April 3rd, in Swakopmund it is not allowed to relax at the beach, to surf or do shore angling.

On the 14th of April 2020, Namibian President addressed the nation regarding the reopening of schools. He stated that teachers and lectures will operate from home during the period of 20th April 2020, and will officially return to places of work on Wednesday, 6th May 2020. Learners and students will not return to school until further notice.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that most businesses where social distancing is possible will be permitted to reopen, subject to responsible personal and organizational conduct and in compliance with the Health & Hygiene Guidelines. Business that are not open for business are; Theatres; cinemas; Gyms and exercise centers; Contact sports and sporting events; Gambling houses; nightclubs; Entertainment events and concerts; Liquor outlets, bars and shebeens; Seminars, Conferences, Workshops and Summits. The penalty for violating these Stage 2 regulations is a spot fine of N$2,000 or arrest.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The announcement of the easing of lockdown restrictions in Namibia on the 30th of April, stated that the public should continue Social Distancing protocols of at least 1.5 meters between persons, to minimize the potential of spread of the disease within the communities.
